The 'McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II' is a tandem, two-seat, twin-engine, all-
weather, long-range supersonic jet interceptor fighter/fighter-bomber originally
developed for the United States Navy by McDonnell Aircraft. Swanborough and Bowers 1976, p. 301. It first entered service in
1960 with the U.S. Navy. Proving highly adaptable, it was also adopted by the
U.S. Marine Corps and the U.S. Air Force, and by the mid-1960s had become a
major part of their respective air wings.

The Phantom is a large fighter with a top speed of over Mach 2.2. It can
carry over 18,000 pounds (8,400 kg) of weapons on nine external hardpoints,
including air-to-air missiles, air-to-ground missiles, and various bombs. The
F-4, like other interceptors of its time, was designed without an internal
cannon. Later models incorporated a M61 Vulcan rotary cannon. Beginning in 1959
it set 15 world records for in-flight performance, [h-
ttp://web.archive.org/web/20110629074601/http://www.boeing.com/defense-
space/military/f4/firsts.htm "Phabulous 40th: Phantom "Phirsts"."] Boeing.
Retrieved: 27 November 2012. including an absolute speed record, and an
absolute altitude record. [http://www.boeing.com/defense-
space/military/f4/bluebook/record.htm "Phabulous 40th: World Record Holder."]
Boeing. Retrieved: 14 December 2007.

During the Vietnam War the F-4 was used extensively; it served as the principal
air superiority fighter for both the Navy and Air Force, and became important in
the ground-attack and reconnaissance roles late in the war. The Phantom has the
distinction of being the last U.S. fighter flown to attain ace status in the
20th century. During the Vietnam War the USAF had one pilot and two weapon
systems officers (WSOs), and the US Navy one pilot and
one radar intercept officer (RIO), achieve five aerial kills against other enemy
fighter aircraft and become aces in air-to-air combat.
The F-4 continued to form a major part of U.S. military air power throughout the
1970s and 1980s, being gradually replaced by more modern aircraft such as the
F-15 Eagle and F-16 in the U.S. Air Force; the Grumman F-14 Tomcat and F/A-18
Hornet in the U.S. Navy; and the F/A-18 in the U.S. Marine Corps.

The F-4 Phantom II remained in use by the U.S. in the reconnaissance and Wild
Weasel (suppression of enemy air defenses) roles in the 1991 Gulf War, finally
leaving service in 1996. Donald Spring 1991, p. 26. Donald Summer 1991, p. 22. It was also the only
aircraft used by both U.S. flight demonstration teams: the USAF Thunderbirds (F-
4E) and the US Navy Blue Angels (F-4J). Lake 1992, p. 190. Lake 1992, p. 203. The F-4 was
also operated by the armed forces of 11 other nations. Israeli Phantoms saw
extensive combat in several ArabâIsraeli conflicts, while Iran used its large
fleet of Phantoms in the IranâIraq War. Phantoms remain in front line service
with seven countries, and in use as an unmanned target in the U.S. Air
Force. Phantom production ran from 1958 to 1981, with a
total of 5,195 built, making it the most numerous American supersonic military
aircraft. [http://web.archive.org/web/20110629034016/http:/-
/www.boeing.com/defense-space/military/f4/index.htm "F-4 Phantoms Phabulous
40th".] Boeing. Retrieved: 27 November 2012. [http://www.boeing.com/defense-
space/military/f4/firstlast.htm "Phabulous 40th: First to Last."] Boeing.
Retrieved: 19 November 2007.
